deeperData.description: Incorrect parsing of certain JSON input may result in js-bson not correctly serializing BSON. This may cause unexpected application behaviour including data disclosure. This issue affects: MongoDB Inc. js-bson library version 1.1.3 and prior to.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `bson` package is vulnerable to Untrusted Data Deserialization. The bson serializer does not invalidate unknown `_bsontype` values in objects and proceeds to serialize them as a document, allowing for untrusted data to be smuggled into the data object. An attacker can smuggle data to be serialized/deserialized by any service utilizing bson data.

*Vulnerable File(s) and Function(s)*:

package/lib/bson/parser/serializer.js
* serializeInto()

package/lib/bson/bson_new.js
* serializeInto()

package/browser_build/bson.js
* serializeInto()

package/alternate_parsers/bson.js
* packElement()

package/lib/bson/bson.js
* packElement()

package/dist/bson.bundle.js
* serializeInto()

package/dist/bson.js
* serializeInto()

package/dist/bson.esm.js
* serializeInto()

package/dist/bson.browser.umd.js
* serializeInto()

package/dist/bson.browser.esm.js
* serializeInto()

deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `mocha` package is vulnerable to Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) attacks. The `clean` function in the `utils.js` file uses an insecure regular expression to strip the function definition from a user supplied string while creating and manipulating `Doc`, `Markdown` and `Html` reporter instances. A remote attacker can exploit this vulnerability by supplying a long malformed function definition to the affected function in order to trigger exponential backtracking and ultimately result in a DoS condition.

deeperData.description: the web framework using ljharb's qs module older than v6.3.2, v6.2.3, v6.1.2, and v6.0.4 is vulnerable to a DoS. A malicious user can send a evil request to cause the web framework crash.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `qs` package is vulnerable to a Denial of Service attack due to improper input validation. The `parseKeys()` function in `parse.js` and `qs.js` allows unwanted braces (`[` or `]`) inside the query string parameters. These will create nested objects while parsing and overwrite the object's properties, causing unexpected behavior of the `hasOwnProperty()` function and potentially crashing the application. A remote attacker can exploit this vulnerability by crafting a malicious request containing braces and regular expressions (`///[`) inside the query string parameter, resulting in a DOS.

deeperData.description: qs before 6.10.3, as used in Express before 4.17.3 and other products, allows attackers to cause a Node process hang for an Express application because an __ proto__ key can be used. In many typical Express use cases, an unauthenticated remote attacker can place the attack payload in the query string of the URL that is used to visit the application, such as a[__proto__]=b&a[__proto__]&a[length]=100000000. The fix was backported to qs 6.9.7, 6.8.3, 6.7.3, 6.6.1, 6.5.3, 6.4.1, 6.3.3, and 6.2.4 (and therefore Express 4.17.3, which has "deps: qs@6.9.7" in its release description, is not vulnerable).
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `qs` package, as used by `express`, is vulnerable to Prototype Pollution. The `parseObject()` function in the `parse.js` file allows for modification of object prototype properties via `__proto__`. A remote attacker can exploit this vulnerability to override the prototyped behavior of objects by requesting a URL that leverages arrays containing prototype accessors. Depending on how the tampered object is used by the application, this may result in a Denial of Service (DoS), Remote Code Execution (RCE), or other unexpected behavior.

Example:
`categories[_proto__]&categories[_proto__]&categories[length]=100000000`

Reference: [https://github.com/n8tz/CVE-2022-24999](https://github.com/n8tz/CVE-2022-24999)

*Advisory Deviation Notice*: The Sonatype security research team discovered that this vulnerability was introduced into `qs` in version 1.0.0 and therefore does not affect all versions prior to 6.2.4 as stated in the advisory. Additionally, it was discovered that `express` began using vulnerable versions of `qs` in version 1.0.4.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `qs` package is vulnerable to a Improper Input Validation. Under normal conditions, the `parseKeys` and `parseObject` functions in `parse.js` will take the parameter names and values of a querystring and turn them into JavaScript objects with matching keys and values, which are then combined into a single object by the `merge` function in `utils.js`.  An exception to this is when a parameter's name and value are not converted into an object, but some other data type, such as a string.  When this happens, the `merge` function will simply add the resulting string to the resulting object as a property with a value of `true`.  This condition occurs when it parses a query string with a parameter whose name starts with a square bracket, such as "]evil=toString".  This will cause the query string object's `toString` property to be overwritten with the value `true`.  An attacker can exploit this behavior to overwrite any of the query string object's properties, which could potentially bypass any security mechanisms in place that relied on those properties.

deeperData.description: hoek node module before 4.2.0 and 5.0.x before 5.0.3 suffers from a Modification of Assumed-Immutable Data (MAID) vulnerability via 'merge' and 'applyToDefaults' functions, which allows a malicious user to modify the prototype of "Object" via __proto__, causing the addition or modification of an existing property that will exist on all objects.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `hoek` package is vulnerable to Prototype Pollution attacks.  The `merge()` function (and the `applyToDefaults()` and `applyToDefaultsWithShallow()` functions which also employ it) in the `index.js` file takes an unsanitized user supplied JSON string that is used to merge with another JSON object. This user supplied string can contain the "__proto__" property and be used to modify the prototype property of a JavaScript object. An attacker can exploit this by overwriting existing properties, leading to a potential crash and denial of service, or adding new malicious properties that could then be parsed and executed.

deeperData.description: minimist before 1.2.2 could be tricked into adding or modifying properties of Object.prototype using a "constructor" or "__proto__" payload.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `minimist` package is vulnerable to Prototype Pollution. The `setKey` function in `index.js` modifies JavaScript objects based on user input. An attacker can exploit this behavior to modify the behavior of `Object.prototype`, causing all other objects in the code to behave in unexpected and malicious ways.

*Advisory Deviation Notice:* The Sonatype security research team discovered that the fix for this vulnerability was backported to 0.2.1 for the 0.X versions.

deeperData.description: json-schema is vulnerable to Improperly Controlled Modification of Object Prototype Attributes ('Prototype Pollution')
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `json-schema` package is vulnerable to Prototype Pollution. The `checkObj()` function in the `validate.js` file allows for modification of prototype properties via certain accessors such as `__proto__`. An attacker with control over input to the library may craft schemas with polluted object properties that when used to validate an object, may result in Denial of Service (DoS), and under certain circumstances Remote Code Execution (RCE).

deeperData.description: Lodash versions prior to 4.17.21 are vulnerable to Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) via the toNumber, trim and trimEnd functions.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `lodash` package contains a Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) vulnerability. The `lodash.js`, `trimEnd.js`, `trim.js`, `toNumber.js`, and `parseInt.js` files contain a vulnerable regular expression used for trimming whitespace on strings. An attacker can exploit this with a large input string that would take an exponentially long amount of time to parse, resulting in a Denial of Service (DoS).

*Advisory Deviation Notice:* The Sonatype security research team has discovered that the root cause of the vulnerability is in version 4.0.0, not in all versions as the advisory implies. In other words, versions prior to 4.0.0 are not vulnerable to this flaw.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `lodash` package is vulnerable to Command Injection. The `template` function in `lodash.js` and `template.js` does not properly ensure the `variable` property of the `options` parameter to be a valid EcmaScript identifier. An attacker can exploit this by passing in a malicious command as the `variable` property, which would then be executed.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `lodash` package is vulnerable to Prototype Pollution. The `template` function in `lodash.js`, `template.js`, and `lodash.min.js` does not account for unicode newline characters when filtering the `sourceURL` property of the `options` object. Because of how the `options` object is used, an attacker who can control the source URL can leverage this to alter properties on the prototype chain, which can cause other sections of code to behave in an arbitrary and malicious way.

Please note that this vulnerability is due to an incomplete fix in sonatype-2019-0500.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown:
The application is vulnerable by using this component, but the following conditions apply:

Version 4.17.16 of `lodash` (as present in npm downloads) has eliminated the vulnerable regex in the file `package/lodash.js`. The fixed regex is introduced in `package/lodash.js` starting in version 4.17.17. However, all versions >=4.17.12 (including 4.17.16, 4.17.17, etc.) continue to contain the vulnerable regex in the `package/template.js` file until the fix is found in version 4.17.20 of npm downloads.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `lodash` and `lodash.zipobjectdeep` packages are vulnerable to Prototype Pollution. The `baseSet`, `set` and `setWith` functions in `lodash.js` and the `zipObjectDeep` function in the `lodash.zipobjectdeep` package, fail to restrict the addition or modification of properties of `Object` prototypes. A remote attacker can exploit this behavior to modify `Object` prototype properties which, depending on the behavior of the object within the application, can result in a Denial of Service (DoS) or potentially Remote Code Execution (RCE).

NOTE #1: This vulnerability has been assigned CVE-2020-8203.

NOTE #2: The following HackerOne reports are also addressed by the fix for this CVE.
* https://hackerone.com/reports/841380
* https://hackerone.com/reports/864701

*Advisory Deviation Notice:* The Sonatype security research team discovered that the fix for this vulnerability was actually introduced in version 4.17.17 as opposed to the 4.17.19 version stated by the [npm advisory](https://www.npmjs.com/advisories/1523). However, versions 4.17.16 to 4.17.18 [were corrupted](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/wiki/Changelog#v41719) and we recommend upgrading to version 4.17.19.

The `lodash` package is vulnerable to Prototype Pollution. The `baseSet` function in `_baseSet.js` fails to restrict the addition or modification of properties of `Object` prototypes. A remote attacker can exploit this behavior to modify `Object` prototype properties which, depending on the behavior of the object within the application, can result in a Denial of Service (DoS) or potentially Remote Code Execution (RCE).

NOTE: This vulnerability exists due to a fix for [CVE-2020-8203](https://github.com/lodash/lodash/issues/4874) having been applied only to select files.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `path-parse` package is vulnerable to Regular expression Denial of Service (ReDoS). The `win32SplitPath()` and `posixSplitPath()` functions in the `index.js` file use insecure regular expressions to parse and split file paths in a given input. A remote attacker that can influence `pathstrings`, can exploit this vulnerability by supplying an input that consists of a large number of forward or backslashes followed by any character that makes the regex fail, such as a semicolon. This will trigger catastrophic backtracking and result in a DoS condition when the application attempts to process the attacker-supplied data.

*Note:* This vulnerability has been assigned CVE-2021-23343.

deeperData.description: Versions of the npm CLI prior to 6.14.6 are vulnerable to an information exposure vulnerability through log files. The CLI supports URLs like "<protocol>://[<user>[:<password>]@]<hostname>[:<port>][:][/]<path>". The password value is not redacted and is printed to stdout and also to any generated log files.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `npm` package is vulnerable to Information Leakage. The `npm-cli.js` file and the `andLogAndFinish` function in `fetch-package-metadata.js` and the `errorMessage` function in `error-message.js` and the `errorHandler` function in `error-handler.js` logs messages that can contain sensitive information. A local attacker could exploit this behavior to obtain information from logged information that would not otherwise be unobtainable.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `npm` package is vulnerable to Memory Mismanagement.  The `setCredentialsByURI` method in `set-credentials-by-uri.js`, the `getCredentialsByURI` method in `get-credentials-by-uri.js`, and the `write` method in `version.js` use the deprecated `new Buffer` convention. deeperData.description: Versions of the npm CLI prior to 6.13.3 are vulnerable to an Arbitrary File Write. It is possible for packages to create symlinks to files outside of thenode_modules folder through the bin field upon installation. A properly constructed entry in the package.json bin field would allow a package publisher to create a symlink pointing to arbitrary files on a user's system when the package is installed. This behavior is still possible through install scripts. This vulnerability bypasses a user using the --ignore-scripts install option.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `npm` package is vulnerable to Improper Input Validation due to UNIX Symbolic Link (Symlink) Following. Multiple functions in multiple files, as listed below, do not properly validate the values provided in the `package.json` file. A package publisher can exploit this vulnerability by crafting a malicious entry in `package.json`  to overwrite arbitrary files (via symlinks) on the target host.



*Vulnerable File(s) and Function(s)*:

package/node_modules/bin-links/index.js
* binLinks()
* linkBins()
* linkMans()

package/lib/build.js
* function()
* linkBins()
* linkMans()

package/node_modules/npm-bundled/index.js
* onPackageJson()

package/node_modules/npm-packlist/node_modules/npm-bundled/index.js
* onPackageJson()

package/node_modules/npm-packlist/index.js
* onReadIgnoreFile()

package/node_modules/pacote/lib/fetchers/directory.js
* manifest()

package/node_modules/libcipm/node_modules/pacote/lib/fetchers/directory.js
* manifest()

package/node_modules/pacote/lib/finalize-manifest.js
* Manifest()

package/node_modules/libcipm/node_modules/pacote/lib/finalize-manifest.js
* Manifest()

package/node_modules/read-package-json/read-json.js
* bins()
* bins_()

deeperData.description: Versions of the npm CLI prior to 6.13.4 are vulnerable to an Arbitrary File Overwrite. It fails to prevent existing globally-installed binaries to be overwritten by other package installations. For example, if a package was installed globally and created a serve binary, any subsequent installs of packages that also create a serve binary would overwrite the previous serve binary. This behavior is still allowed in local installations and also through install scripts. This vulnerability bypasses a user using the --ignore-scripts install option.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `npm` package is vulnerable to Arbitrary File Overwrite. Multiple functions in multiple files, as listed below, do not prevent package installations from overwriting existing installations in global scope. An attacker can exploit this vulnerability to potentially overwrite files present in sensitive locations, such as `/usr/local/bin`.


*Vulnerable File(s) and Function(s)*:

package/node_modules/bin-links/index.js
* linkBin()
* linkMans()

deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `path-parse` package is vulnerable to Regular expression Denial of Service (ReDoS). The `win32SplitPath()` and `posixSplitPath()` functions in the `index.js` file use insecure regular expressions to parse and split file paths in a given input. A remote attacker that can influence `pathstrings`, can exploit this vulnerability by supplying an input that consists of a large number of forward or backslashes followed by any character that makes the regex fail, such as a semicolon. This will trigger catastrophic backtracking and result in a DoS condition when the application attempts to process the attacker-supplied data.

*Note:* This vulnerability has been assigned CVE-2021-23343.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `express` package is vulnerable to HTTP Response Splitting. The `redirect()` function in the file `response.js` allows Carriage Return and Line Feed (CRLF) characters in the user input, which is then injected into the HTTP response. A remote attacker can exploit the vulnerability by crafting user input with the CRLF characters which will allow the attacker to set arbitrary HTTP response headers and control the body of the HTTP response.  Likewise, any sensitive information, such as authentication tokens that are returned in the HTTP response sequentially after the injection point, will be accessible to the attacker.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown:
The application is vulnerable by using this component with NodeJS runtime versions less than 0.9.4.  NodeJS runtime versions including and after 0.9.4 have built in response splitting protections, effectively remediating the issue at the runtime level.
 
See [https://github.com/expressjs/express/pull/974](https://github.com/expressjs/express/pull/974) for more details.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown: While there is no non-vulnerable version of this component, the vulnerability was fixed at the runtime level (within NodeJS itself). Upgrading NodeJS to a version after or including 0.9.4 will remediate this issue.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `chownr` package is vulnerable to Time-of-check Time-of-use (TOCTOU) Race Condition attacks. The `chownr()` method in the file `chownr.js` file can be used to the change ownership of the given files/directories recursively. It fails to prevent changing the ownership of the symbolic-link referer(s) while performing recursive ownership change of files/directories since it uses `chown()` instead of `lchown()`. 
In general, `lchown()` changes the ownership of the symbolic link files, whereas `chown()` changes the ownership of the file/directory referred to by the symbolic link only. This functionality can therefore be abused by an attacker to change the ownership/permissions of unintended files/directory.

deeperData.recommendationMarkdown: We recommend upgrading to a version of this component that is not vulnerable to this specific issue.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `revalidator` package contains a Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) vulnerability. The `validateProperty` function in the `revalidator.js` file uses an insecure regular expression to validate URL format extensions. A remote attacker can exploit this vulnerability by crafting a request containing a url that starts with a valid protocol, `(https|ftp|git)://`, followed by a long repetitive sequence of dot separated numeric characters. This will trigger catastrophic backtracking and result in a Denial of Service condition once the application attempts to process the attacker supplied data.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component with the `validateFormatExtensions` options set to `true`, which is the default behavior.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown: There is no non-vulnerable upgrade path for this component/package. We recommend investigating alternative components or a potential mitigating control.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `hawk` package is vulnerable to a Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS). The `parseHost()` and `parseAuthorizationHeader()` methods in `utils.js` do not limit the HTTP header's length. Also, the `authenticateBewit()` method in `server.js` does not limit the URI's length. When a large input string is passed to any of the aforementioned methods, it will result in very slow processing causing the application to hang. A remote attacker can exploit this vulnerability by sending a request with a very large header or URI to an application using Hawk to cause a Denial of Service. 

Sample Attack: 
```
var header = Hawk.client.header('http://localhost:8000/resource/location/testfolder/testfolder2/testfolder3/1?b=1&a=2&payloadString=<<greater than 4096 length string>>', 'GET', { credentials: credentials, ext: 'some-app-data' });
requestOptions.headers.Authorization = header.field;
```

Note: This vulnerability has been assigned a CVE ID of CVE-2016-2515
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this package.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown: We recommend upgrading to a version of this component that is not vulnerable to this specific issue.

deeperData.description: Hawk is an HTTP authentication scheme providing mechanisms for making authenticated HTTP requests with partial cryptographic verification of the request and response, covering the HTTP method, request URI, host, and optionally the request payload. Hawk used a regular expression to parse `Host` HTTP header (`Hawk.utils.parseHost()`), which was subject to regular expression DoS attack - meaning each added character in the attacker's input increases the computation time exponentially. `parseHost()` was patched in `9.0.1` to use built-in `URL` class to parse hostname instead. `Hawk.authenticate()` accepts `options` argument. If that contains `host` and `port`, those would be used instead of a call to `utils.parseHost()`.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `hawk` package is vulnerable to Regular expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) attacks. The `parseHost()` function in the `utils.js` file uses an unsafe regular expression to parse the user-supplied `Host` header. A remote attacker can exploit this vulnerability by providing a header that leverages a long string of characters to cause catastrophic backtracking and ultimately a Denial of Service (DoS) condition.

*Advisory Deviation Notice:* The Sonatype security research team discovered that User Interaction is not required to exploit this vulnerability and the scope doesn't change; hence the CVSS Base score is 7.5 instead of 7.4 as the advisory stated.

deeperData.description: Versions of the npm CLI prior to 6.13.3 are vulnerable to an Arbitrary File Write. It is possible for packages to create symlinks to files outside of thenode_modules folder through the bin field upon installation. A properly constructed entry in the package.json bin field would allow a package publisher to create a symlink pointing to arbitrary files on a user's system when the package is installed. This behavior is still possible through install scripts. This vulnerability bypasses a user using the --ignore-scripts install option.

A package publisher can exploit this vulnerability by crafting a malicious entry in `package.json`  to overwrite arbitrary files (via symlinks) on the target host.

deeperData.description: ctorName in index.js in kind-of v6.0.2 allows external user input to overwrite certain internal attributes via a conflicting name, as demonstrated by 'constructor': {'name':'Symbol'}. Hence, a crafted payload can overwrite this builtin attribute to manipulate the type detection result.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `kind-of` package is vulnerable to Improper Input Validation. The `ctorName` function in `index.js` does not properly verify or sanitize user input, specifically with regards to the `constructor.name` attribute. An attacker can exploit this vulnerability by providing a conflicting function name within the input to overwrite this internal attribute, and override type detection result in the application leading to inconsistencies.

*Advisory Deviation Notice:* The Sonatype security research team discovered that the vulnerability is present in versions 6.0.0 and above of the package, with a fix having been released in version 6.0.3. Whereas, the [NVD advisory](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2019-20149) originally stated only version 6.0.2 being vulnerable.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `minimatch` package is vulnerable to Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) attacks. The `braceExpand` function in the `minimatch.js` file uses an insecure regular expression to parse a user supplied string in order to perform brace expansion. A remote attacker can exploit this vulnerability by submitting an input containing a valid start to a brace expression, `a{`, followed by many repeating opening key braces, `{`, and ending with any alphanumeric character. This will result in a DoS condition once the attacker supplied input is processed. 

>Example payload: `attack_str = 'a'+'{'.repeat(10000)+"b"`
Reference: [https://www.huntr.dev/bounties/e4e1393c-d590-4492-9f43-8be3f3321629/](https://www.huntr.dev/bounties/e4e1393c-d590-4492-9f43-8be3f3321629/)

deeperData.description: adm-zip npm library before 0.4.9 is vulnerable to directory traversal, allowing attackers to write to arbitrary files via a ../ (dot dot slash) in a Zip archive entry that is mishandled during extraction. This vulnerability is also known as 'Zip-Slip'.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `adm-zip` is vulnerable to path traversal.  The extraction methods in `adm-zip.js` do not validate the resolved absolute path of the files in an archive before extraction.  An attacker can exploit this by providing an archive with path traversal characters in one of the archive's file's names, causing it to be extracted outside the intended directory.  Since this allows arbitrary files to be written to unintended locations on the vulnerable server, depending on configuration, this could lead to sensitive files being overwritten and Arbitrary Code Execution.

deeperData.description: The package hosted-git-info before 3.0.8 are vulnerable to Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) via regular expression shortcutMatch in the fromUrl function in index.js. The affected regular expression exhibits polynomial worst-case time complexity.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `hosted-git-info` package is vulnerable to Regular expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) attacks. The `fromUrl()` function in the `index.js` file uses an unsafe regular expression to parse user-supplied Git URLs. A remote attacker can exploit this vulnerability by providing a URL that leverages a long string of repeating characters to cause catastrophic backtracking and ultimately a Denial of Service (DoS) condition.

Example:  
`'a:' + ['a' * 10000] + '/'`

*Advisory Deviation Notice*: The Sonatype security research team discovered that this vulnerability was introduced in version 2.3.1 and therefore does not affect all versions before 3.0.8 as stated in the advisory.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `js-yaml` package is vulnerable to a Denial of Service (DoS) attack. The `storeMappingPair()` function in the `loader.js` file fails to disallow nested arrays as map keys. A remote attacker can exploit this vulnerability by submitting malicious `yaml` containing deeply nested data structures that reference each other. This will result in exponential expansion and ultimately a DoS condition when the application attempts to process the provided `yaml`.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown: We recommend upgrading to a version of this component that is not vulnerable to this specific issue.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `js-yaml` package is vulnerable to Remote Code Execution (RCE). The `storeMappingPair()` function in the `loader.js` file allows for the execution of code contained within a `toString` property in provided `yaml` data. A remote attacker can exploit this vulnerability by submitting malicious `yaml` data with a `toString` property that contains malicious code. This will result in the execution of the attacker-provided code when the application attempts to process the `yaml` data.

Example:
```
$ cat test.yaml
{ toString: !<tag:yaml.org,2002:js/function> 'function (){return Date.now()}' } : 1

$ ./bin/js-yaml.js ./test.yaml 
{
  "1553107949161": 1
}
```
Reference: [https://github.com/nodeca/js-yaml/pull/480#issue-267877885](https://github.com/nodeca/js-yaml/pull/480#issue-267877885)

deeperData.description: shelljs is vulnerable to Improper Privilege Management
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `shelljs` package is vulnerable due to Improper Privilege Management. The `execSync()` function in the `exec.js` file does not properly ensure if a user is authorized to read and write to the `paramFiles`, `stdoutFile` and `stderrFile` before allowing the user to access them. A local attacker with low privileges can exploit this behavior to obtain sensitive information from the aforementioned files.  The attacker can also create a `stdoutFile` or `stderrFile` first, which will crash the `exec` process when it tries to write to these files, resulting in a Denial of Service (DoS) condition.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `shelljs` package is vulnerable to an OS Command Injection attack. The `exec()` function in the `shell.js` file executes shell commands which are obtained from external sources. A remote attacker can exploit this vulnerability by passing a malicious OS command as part of the shell command which when processed can lead to OS command injection. 

*Note:* The intended functionality of this component is to perform shell execution. Because of this, Sonatype does not necessarily consider this a vulnerability. However, if you are passing untrusted data to the `exec()` method, then command injection is possible and the untrusted data should be validated.

**NOTE:** An incomplete fix made for this vulnerability may affect some versions of npm `lodash`, e.g. 4.17.5 and above, as covered by CVE-2018-16487.

deeperData.description: In Async before 2.6.4 and 3.x before 3.2.2, a malicious user can obtain privileges via the mapValues() method, aka lib/internal/iterator.js createObjectIterator prototype pollution.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `async` package is vulnerable to Prototype Pollution. The `createObjectIterator()` function in the `internal/iterator.js` file allows for modification of object prototype properties via certain accessors, such as `__proto__`. A remote attacker who can influence data propagated to the affected function, via `mapValues()` or other means, can exploit this vulnerability to alter the prototyped behavior of objects. Depending on the application's usage of the modified object, this may result in a Denial of Service (DoS), Remote Code Execution (RCE), or other unexpected behavior.

*Advisory Deviation Notice*: The Sonatype security research team discovered that this vulnerability was introduced in version 2.0.0-rc.2 and therefore does not affect all versions prior to 2.6.4 as stated in the advisory.

deeperData.description: The qs module before 1.0.0 in Node.js does not call the compact function for array data, which allows remote attackers to cause a denial of service (memory consumption) by using a large index value to create a sparse array.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The lack of nesting array compaction and failure to handle exceptional conditions for the user input before the creation of sparse arrays by the `querystring-parser` of the querystring (qs) module in 'nodejs', leaves it prone to memory overflows and the denial of service (DoS) attack through memory exhaustion, which results in the node process crash.

When a remote attacker sends an input containing a very high index (for example: `foo[0][100000000]=bar`) to create a large array of objects, the parser will create an array with an array of null objects at the first index of the object that will eventually consume/exhaust all the allocated memory of the running process causing denial of service (DoS), resulting in a crash of the node process.

deeperData.description: hoek node module before 4.2.0 and 5.0.x before 5.0.3 suffers from a Modification of Assumed-Immutable Data (MAID) vulnerability via 'merge' and 'applyToDefaults' functions, which allows a malicious user to modify the prototype of "Object" via __proto__, causing the addition or modification of an existing property that will exist on all objects.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `hoek` package is vulnerable to Prototype Pollution attacks.  The `merge()` function (and the `applyToDefaults()` and `applyToDefaultsWithShallow()` functions which also employ it) in the `index.js` file takes an unsanitized user supplied JSON string that is used to merge with another JSON object. This user supplied string can contain the "__proto__" property and be used to modify the prototype property of a JavaScript object. An attacker can exploit this by overwriting existing properties, leading to a potential crash and denial of service, or adding new malicious properties that could then be parsed and executed.

deeperData.description: jQuery before 3.4.0, as used in Drupal, Backdrop CMS, and other products, mishandles jQuery.extend(true, {}, ...) because of Object.prototype pollution. If an unsanitized source object contained an enumerable __proto__ property, it could extend the native Object.prototype.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `jquery` package is vulnerable to Prototype Pollution. The `jQuery.extend` and `jQuery.fn.extend` functions defined in many files allow an untrusted object to extend `Object.prototype`. An attacker can modify and add prototype properties to JavaScript objects and can potentially leverage those changes to crash the application or execute remote code.

*Advisory Deviation Notice:* The Sonatype security research team has assessed the CVSS score for this vulnerability to be 7.5 given the nature of prototype pollution and the high impact to data integrity, as opposed to a score of 6.1 reported by [NVD](https://nvd.nist.gov/vuln/detail/CVE-2019-11358).

deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `marked` package is vulnerable to Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) attacks via Catastrophic Backtracking. The `marked.js` file contains several regular expressions that contain patterns which can be validated by a large number of variations. Meaning, if the pattern is validated in one way, and the regex engine moves on to the next pattern, only to have it not be validated, the engine then backtracks to the previous pattern and tries to validate it another way. If it succeeds again, and then fails on the next pattern again, the cycle continues, trying all of the variations to validate the pattern. An attacker can exploit this by inputting a long string containing characters which can satisfy the vulnerable pattern with a large number of variations followed by a character that does not match the next pattern. When parsed by the regex engine, this will cause uncontrolled resource consumption as the engine tries to match the entire regular expression and fails repeatedly, as it goes through all the possible variations, ultimately resulting in a Denial of Service (DoS).

deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `marked` component is vulnerable to a Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) attack.  When specific input is supplied to `marked`, the application will hang as it tries to process a certain regular expression against the malicious input. In a server-side, NodeJS environment, this is particularly severe as NodeJS is single-threaded. An attacker can exploit this vulnerability to cause the application process to become unresponsive, thus blocking subsequent requests from being fulfilled if used in a server-side setting.

*NOTE:* This vulnerability is the same as CVE-2017-17461 which was rejected erroneously (see https://blog.sonatype.com/cve-2017-17461-vulnerable-or-not).

deeperData.description: The got package before 12.1.0 (also fixed in 11.8.5) for Node.js allows a redirect to a UNIX socket.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:

deeperData.description: Hawk is an HTTP authentication scheme providing mechanisms for making authenticated HTTP requests with partial cryptographic verification of the request and response, covering the HTTP method, request URI, host, and optionally the request payload. Hawk used a regular expression to parse `Host` HTTP header (`Hawk.utils.parseHost()`), which was subject to regular expression DoS attack - meaning each added character in the attacker's input increases the computation time exponentially. `parseHost()` was patched in `9.0.1` to use built-in `URL` class to parse hostname instead. `Hawk.authenticate()` accepts `options` argument. If that contains `host` and `port`, those would be used instead of a call to `utils.parseHost()`.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `hawk` package is vulnerable to Regular expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) attacks. The `parseHost()` function in the `utils.js` file uses an unsafe regular expression to parse the user-supplied `Host` header. A remote attacker can exploit this vulnerability by providing a header that leverages a long string of characters to cause catastrophic backtracking and ultimately a Denial of Service (DoS) condition.

*Advisory Deviation Notice:* The Sonatype security research team discovered that User Interaction is not required to exploit this vulnerability and the scope doesn't change; hence the CVSS Base score is 7.5 instead of 7.4 as the advisory stated.

deeperData.description: qs before 6.10.3, as used in Express before 4.17.3 and other products, allows attackers to cause a Node process hang for an Express application because an __ proto__ key can be used. In many typical Express use cases, an unauthenticated remote attacker can place the attack payload in the query string of the URL that is used to visit the application, such as a[__proto__]=b&a[__proto__]&a[length]=100000000. The fix was backported to qs 6.9.7, 6.8.3, 6.7.3, 6.6.1, 6.5.3, 6.4.1, 6.3.3, and 6.2.4 (and therefore Express 4.17.3, which has "deps: qs@6.9.7" in its release description, is not vulnerable).
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `qs` package, as used by `express`, is vulnerable to Prototype Pollution. The `parseObject()` function in the `parse.js` file allows for modification of object prototype properties via `__proto__`. A remote attacker can exploit this vulnerability to override the prototyped behavior of objects by requesting a URL that leverages arrays containing prototype accessors. Depending on how the tampered object is used by the application, this may result in a Denial of Service (DoS), Remote Code Execution (RCE), or other unexpected behavior.

Example:
`categories[_proto__]&categories[_proto__]&categories[length]=100000000`

Reference: [https://github.com/n8tz/CVE-2022-24999](https://github.com/n8tz/CVE-2022-24999)

*Advisory Deviation Notice*: The Sonatype security research team discovered that this vulnerability was introduced into `qs` in version 1.0.0 and therefore does not affect all versions prior to 6.2.4 as stated in the advisory. Additionally, it was discovered that `express` began using vulnerable versions of `qs` in version 1.0.4.

deeperData.description: Path Traversal in GitHub repository gruntjs/grunt prior to 1.5.2.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `grunt` package is vulnerable to Path Traversal attacks. When copying the contents of a directory, the `file.copy()` function in `file.js` will resolve symlinks and copy their target instead of copying the symlinks themselves. A malicious user with write access to the source or destination directories supplied as parameters to the `file.copy()` function could create symlinks to restricted files at those locations. When `file.copy()` is invoked by the root user, or by a scheduled task running as root, this could result in the restricted files being overwritten or copied with insecure permissions. An attacker could leverage this vulnerability to gain access to the `/etc/shadow` file and crack the password hashes it contains, or replace it with their own, granting them root access to the system.

This vulnerability is capable of arbitrary file writes which can lead to local privilege escalation to the GruntJS user if a lower-privileged user has write access to both source and destination directories as the lower-privileged user can create a symlink to the GruntJS user's .bashrc file or replace /etc/shadow file if the GruntJS user is root.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `grunt` package contains an Arbitrary File Write vulnerability. The `copy()` function in the `file.js` file is susceptible to a Time-of-check Time-of-use (TOCTOU) Race Condition in the time between the deletion of the destination symbolic link and writing to the symbolic link. A local attacker with write access to both the `srcpath` and `destpath` directories provided to the affected function can exploit this vulnerability to overwrite arbitrary files or escalate their privileges by leveraging a symlink to the victim's `.bashrc` or `/etc/shadow` files.

Note: This vulnerability exists due to an insufficient fix for CVE-2022-0436.

*Advisory Deviation Notice*: The Sonatype security research team discovered that this vulnerability was introduced in version 1.0.0-rc1 and therefore does not affect all versions prior to 1.5.3 as stated in the advisory.

A remote attacker can exploit this vulnerability by supplying a malicious template which, when processed, will cause the application to consume all available resources, ultimately resulting in a DoS condition.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `minimatch` package is vulnerable to Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) attacks. The `braceExpand` function in the `minimatch.js` file uses an insecure regular expression to parse a user supplied string in order to perform brace expansion. A remote attacker can exploit this vulnerability by submitting an input containing a valid start to a brace expression, `a{`, followed by many repeating opening key braces, `{`, and ending with any alphanumeric character. This will result in a DoS condition once the attacker supplied input is processed. 

>Example payload: `attack_str = 'a'+'{'.repeat(10000)+"b"`
Reference: [https://www.huntr.dev/bounties/e4e1393c-d590-4492-9f43-8be3f3321629/](https://www.huntr.dev/bounties/e4e1393c-d590-4492-9f43-8be3f3321629/)

deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `utile` package is vulnerable to Information Disclosure.  The `encode()` and `decode()` functions in `base64.js` utilize the `Buffer()` constructor native to Node.js to initialize blocks of memory when encoding and decoding Base64-encoded strings.  This function, which may be used to process user input, does not ensure that uninitialized memory stored in the `Buffer` object is cleared before it is used in the encoding and decoding process, which may lead to the exposure of uninitialized memory.  An attacker can exploit this vulnerability by sending a request specifically designed to cause the exposure of uninitialized memory, and examining the response.  The response may contain sensitive information including encryption keys, passwords, and other information that could be leveraged by an attacker to execute further attacks.

deeperData.description: the web framework using ljharb's qs module older than v6.3.2, v6.2.3, v6.1.2, and v6.0.4 is vulnerable to a DoS. A malicious user can send a evil request to cause the web framework crash.
deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `qs` package is vulnerable to a Denial of Service attack due to improper input validation. The `parseKeys()` function in `parse.js` and `qs.js` allows unwanted braces (`[` or `]`) inside the query string parameters. These will create nested objects while parsing and overwrite the object's properties, causing unexpected behavior of the `hasOwnProperty()` function and potentially crashing the application. A remote attacker can exploit this vulnerability by crafting a malicious request containing braces and regular expressions (`///[`) inside the query string parameter, resulting in a DOS.

deeperData.description: qs before 6.10.3, as used in Express before 4.17.3 and other products, allows attackers to cause a Node process hang for an Express application because an __ proto__ key can be used. In many typical Express use cases, an unauthenticated remote attacker can place the attack payload in the query string of the URL that is used to visit the application, such as a[__proto__]=b&a[__proto__]&a[length]=100000000. The fix was backported to qs 6.9.7, 6.8.3, 6.7.3, 6.6.1, 6.5.3, 6.4.1, 6.3.3, and 6.2.4 (and therefore Express 4.17.3, which has "deps: qs@6.9.7" in its release description, is not vulnerable).
deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `qs` package, as used by `express`, is vulnerable to Prototype Pollution. The `parseObject()` function in the `parse.js` file allows for modification of object prototype properties via `__proto__`. A remote attacker can exploit this vulnerability to override the prototyped behavior of objects by requesting a URL that leverages arrays containing prototype accessors. Depending on how the tampered object is used by the application, this may result in a Denial of Service (DoS), Remote Code Execution (RCE), or other unexpected behavior.

Example:
`categories[_proto__]&categories[_proto__]&categories[length]=100000000`

Reference: [https://github.com/n8tz/CVE-2022-24999](https://github.com/n8tz/CVE-2022-24999)

*Advisory Deviation Notice*: The Sonatype security research team discovered that this vulnerability was introduced into `qs` in version 1.0.0 and therefore does not affect all versions prior to 6.2.4 as stated in the advisory. Additionally, it was discovered that `express` began using vulnerable versions of `qs` in version 1.0.4.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `qs` package is vulnerable to a Improper Input Validation. Under normal conditions, the `parseKeys` and `parseObject` functions in `parse.js` will take the parameter names and values of a querystring and turn them into JavaScript objects with matching keys and values, which are then combined into a single object by the `merge` function in `utils.js`.  An exception to this is when a parameter's name and value are not converted into an object, but some other data type, such as a string.  When this happens, the `merge` function will simply add the resulting string to the resulting object as a property with a value of `true`.  This condition occurs when it parses a query string with a parameter whose name starts with a square bracket, such as "]evil=toString".  This will cause the query string object's `toString` property to be overwritten with the value `true`.  An attacker can exploit this behavior to overwrite any of the query string object's properties, which could potentially bypass any security mechanisms in place that relied on those properties.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `npm-user-validate` package is vulnerable to Regular Expression Denial of Service. The `email` function in `validate.js` uses an insecure regular expression to parse the `em` parameter. A remote attacker can exploit this vulnerability by sending an input that starts with an `@` symbol followed by a very long sequence of characters. This will consume all available CPU resources when the application attempts to parse the attacker-supplied data leading to a Denial of Service condition.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown:

Alternatively, a potential workaround is provided at [https://www.npmjs.com/advisories/1572#workarounds](https://www.npmjs.com/advisories/1572#workarounds).  

"Restrict the character length to a reasonable degree before passing a value to .emal(); Also, consider doing a more rigorous sanitizing/validation beforehand."

deeperData.explanationMarkdown:

The `add()` function of `multipart.js` allows for a user to create uninitialized buffers of arbitrary size by sending a number argument in the body type option of the request. A remote attacker can exploit this vulnerability by crafting a multipart POST request with JSON input that has body type option as number to leak the sensitive data in memory.

Example attacks: [https://github.com/request/request/pull/2018](https://github.com/request/request/pull/2018)

deeperData.explanationMarkdown:

The `unescapeHTML()` function in files, `unescapeHTML.js`, `underscore.string.js` and `underscore.string.min.js`, uses an insecure regular expression to replace certain HTML characters. A remote attacker can exploit this vulnerability by submitting large crafted input that exploits this issue. This will result in a DoS when the application attempts to process the supplied data.

*Advisory Deviation Notice:* The Sonatype security research team discovered that the vulnerability is present all versions of the package with no fix having been released yet. Contrary to what the advisory states, version 3.3.5 contains the vulnerable regex in `underscore.string.js` and `underscore.string.min.js`, even if not in `unescapeHTML.js`. deeperData.description: The npm package "tar" (aka node-tar) before versions 6.1.1, 5.0.6, 4.4.14, and 3.3.2 has a arbitrary File Creation/Overwrite vulnerability due to insufficient absolute path sanitization. node-tar aims to prevent extraction of absolute file paths by turning absolute paths into relative paths when the `preservePaths` flag is not set to `true`. This is achieved by stripping the absolute path root from any absolute file paths contained in a tar file. For example `/home/user/.bashrc` would turn into `home/user/.bashrc`. This logic was insufficient when file paths contained repeated path roots such as `////home/user/.bashrc`. `node-tar` would only strip a single path root from such paths. When given an absolute file path with repeating path roots, the resulting path (e.g. `///home/user/.bashrc`) would still resolve to an absolute path, thus allowing arbitrary file creation and overwrite. This issue was addressed in releases 3.2.2, 4.4.14, 5.0.6 and 6.1.1. Users may work around this vulnerability without upgrading by creating a custom `onentry` method which sanitizes the `entry.path` or a `filter` method which removes entries with absolute paths. See referenced GitHub Advisory for details. Be aware of CVE-2021-32803 which fixes a similar bug in later versions of tar.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component with the `preservePaths` flag set to `false` or without the flag at all.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The `js-beautify` and `jsbeautifier` packages are vulnerable to a Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS) attack. The `tokenizer.py` file and the `Tokenizer` function in the `tokenizer.js` file use unsafe regular expressions to parse XML data. A remote attacker who can supply or influence data parsed by an affected `js-beautify` instance can exploit this vulnerability to cause a Denial of Service (DoS) condition.

Example:
```
import jsbeautifier

str = '''
return <- {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {a} {>
'''

print(jsbeautifier.beautify(str, {'e4x': True}))
```
Reference: [https://securitylab.github.com/advisories/GHSL-2021-113-beautify-web-js-beautify/](https://securitylab.github.com/advisories/GHSL-2021-113-beautify-web-js-beautify/)

deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `is-my-json-valid` package is vulnerable to a Regular expression Denial of Service (ReDoS). deeperData.explanationMarkdown:
The request package is vulnerable to Information Disclosure. The node process makes a request with a multipart attachment and body type option as number to the Buffer object which is known for Remote Memory Exposure. The `add()` function of `multipart.js` allows for a user to create uninitialized buffers of arbitrary size by sending a number argument in the body type option of the request. A remote attacker can exploit this vulnerability by crafting a multipart POST request with JSON input that has body type option as number to leak the sensitive data in memory.

Example attacks: [https://github.com/request/request/pull/2018](https://github.com/request/request/pull/2018)

deeperData.explanationMarkdown:

The bson serializer does not invalidate unknown `_bsontype` values in objects and proceeds to serialize them as a document, allowing for untrusted data to be smuggled into the data object. deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `execa` package is vulnerable to Command Injection attacks. When using `execa.shell()`, `execa.shellSync()`, or `execa()` with `shell`=`true`, embedded parameters in the command string can be interpreted as additional OS commands. A remote attacker can exploit this behavior by submitting a crafted request that propagates a command to a parameter embedded in the input string for one of the aforementioned functions. Attackers may leverage this vulnerability to run arbitrary commands on the application server and setup a reverse shell.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component if using `execa.shell()`, `execa.shellSync()`, or `execa()` with `shell`=`true`.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown: We recommend upgrading to a version of this component that is not vulnerable to this specific issue.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `http-signature` package is vulnerable to Information Disclosure due to a Timing Attack.  The `verifyHMAC()` function in `verify.js` uses a non-constant time algorithm to compare the values of HMAC keys.  Because this algorithm runs in non-constant time, an attacker can send a large number of requests and measure the amount of time take to process each one; this data can assist the attacker when determining the correct values to use.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown: We recommend upgrading to a version of this component that is not vulnerable to this specific issue.

deeperData.explanationMarkdown: The `jsonpointer` package is vulnerable to Prototype Pollution. The `setter()` function in the `jsonpointer.js` file allows objects to modify prototype properties via `__proto__`, `constructor`, and `prototype` accessors. A remote attacker can exploit this vulnerability to modify the behavior of object prototypes which, depending on their use in the application, may result in a Denial of Service (DoS), Remote Code Execution (RCE), or other unexpected behavior.
deeperData.detectionMarkdown: The application is vulnerable by using this component.
deeperData.recommendationMarkdown:
We recommend upgrading to a version of this component that is not vulnerable to this specific issue.

Note: If this component is included as a bundled/transitive dependency of another component, there may not be an upgrade path. In this instance, we recommend contacting the maintainers who included the vulnerable package. Alternatively, we recommend investigating alternative components or a potential mitigating control.
